Dear Jolyne J Baarck:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
3/31/25. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan
is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action
plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee
records for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
• (i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial
agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been
determined to be a perpetrator of child
abuse or child neglect. The
2

documentation shall be completed not
more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months
thereafter.
One out of two new hire records reviewed had completed a central registry form
more than 30 days prior to start of employment. The employee was hired on
5/27/24 and the central registry was completed on 4/12/24.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee
records for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
• (j) A written evaluation of the
employee's performance within 30 days
of the completion of the probationary
period or within 180 days, whichever is
less, and a written evaluation of the
employee's performance annually
thereafter.
One out of five employee records reviewed did not have an up-to-date
performance evaluation completed. The employee's last performance evaluation
was completed on 1/31/24.

• (1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following
information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:

documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including
medical and dental services.

including medical and dental care.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical Assistance was provided for R.400.4108. There was discussion around
ensuring financial audits are initiated early enough so that they are completed
within in an annual time frame. The agency is currently in the process of
completing their financial audit. The last one completed was on 2/1/24.
• Technical Assistance was provided for R. 400.4116. The facility had technical
assistance from last year concerning R.400.4166. The agency did not take any
steps to address this issue, and it was not discussed in the Chief Administrator
Assessment. Technical Assistance provided in the interim and renewal reports are
to be discussed in the Chief Administrative Assessment. It is the chief
administrator’s responsibility to ensure compliance is met.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R.400.4116. There appears to be some disconnect between the Chief
Administrator and the staff at the facility. The staff at the facility felt a lack of
“presence” from the chief administrator. The Chief Administrator notes that she
has been absent as of late due to health issues and due to running eight
programs. Weekly meetings will start back up with agendas so that the
communication amongst administration and staff will continue. Consultation was
provided the meetings might want to have agendas and include audit findings and
CAP achievement.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during the licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has not submitted any caps within the last review period.
Financial Overview
I reviewed the financial audit completed on 2/1/24. There has not been an updated
one provided at this time, but they are in the process of completing it. The agency
will provide once it has been finished. There were no issues noted in review of the
2024 budget.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
5

N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
I reviewed the Chief Administrator Assessment. There was not a violation in the
2024 Renewal. Technical Assistance and consultation were provided due to the
discharge summaries not being a fluid document and not having the document
specifically discussing the subsections of R.400.4166. Multiple documents had to
be reviewed to "piece together" compliance. Although this was technical assistance
(TA) and the Chief Administrator Assessment does not speak specifically to TA, the
agency did not correct this issue from last year resulting in violations this year. If TA
is provided, the Chief Administrator Assessment should acknowledge the changes
they have made to stay in compliance in section noted as "Continuous Monitoring
Plan."
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff were interviewed and there were no concerns noted for programing with the
children. However there does appear to be a disconnect in communication between
administration and staff. No youth were placed so youth interviews were not
conducted.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is well maintained and has a home setting. The home is inviting and
clean in all areas. The school/recreation area is decorative and has multiple
recreational items for youth to engage in.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
